change_log.change: Chianti tuning: remove non-alpine altitude drag, soften fatigue/damage for sub-80k runnable profile, add field-loss factors.
Recalibrated based on similar runner data showing 10:30 target. Updated fitness targets and runnable terrain advantages.

racing_experience.competitive_background: Marathon runner progressing to ultra distance

race_history.notes: Top 35% despite twisted ankle and lost inhaler - technical strength evident
Fast time despite cold and respiratory incident - proved Arc is runnable strength race, not survival. Third validation race

training_load.notes: Well-conditioned for ultra distance. CTL 138 at Arc 2025 = fitness 1.15

fitness_progression_targets.notes: Updated based on similar runner data. With focused training post-marathon, 1.15-1.20 achievable for 10:30-11:00 target.

performance_by_gradient._description: Speed capabilities by terrain gradient - validated from UTMB data
performance_by_gradient._note: These are BASE speeds at fitness 1.0, multiply by fitness_level for current capability

steep_downhill.notes: Strong descender, handles technical downhills well

steep_uphill.notes: Efficient hiker on sustained steep climbs

heart_rate.notes: Excellent aerobic efficiency - 74.5% time in Z1 during UTMB

recovery_characteristics.between_races: standard 2-3 weeks for marathon, 4-6 weeks for ultra

respiratory_profile._description: Asthma/respiratory considerations - CRITICAL for race planning
respiratory_profile._importance: This is the PRIMARY limiting factor for performance, especially in cold
respiratory_profile.severity: Moderate - manageable with strategy but significantly impacts performance

baseline_impact.description: Even in perfect conditions, 5% performance penalty vs non-asthmatic baseline

temperature_thresholds.notes: Temperature is the PRIMARY respiratory trigger

cold_impact_validated._source: Chianti simulations with actual cold testing, Arc 2025 validation

8_degrees_c.description: EXTREME RISK - avoid racing if possible

4_8_degrees_c_arc_actual.description: Arc 2025 actual - incident occurred BUT still raced fast. Preventable with inhaler

early_race_km.description: Body not fully warmed up, sustained effort, cold air intake
early_race_km.mitigation: Conservative pacing, control HR, don't surge on climbs

high_effort_sustained.description: Prolonged hard breathing stresses respiratory system
high_effort_sustained.mitigation: Break hard efforts with recovery sections

fitness_effect_on_respiratory.fitness_1.20: Significantly improved - sustained effort less stressful
fitness_effect_on_respiratory.fitness_1.35: Optimal - respiratory system can handle competitive effort
fitness_effect_on_respiratory.notes: Higher fitness = lower HR for same pace = less respiratory stress

recovery_capability.on_descents: Good - HR drops, breathing normalizes within 5-10min
recovery_capability.strategy: Use descents/flats to actively recover respiratory system

preventative: Use buff/neck gaiter to warm air
Avoid surging on climbs when cold
reactive: Immediate pace reduction if breathing difficulty
Use inhaler at first sign of tightness
Drop to HR <130 to allow recovery
67% success rate with immediate intervention vs 31% if pushing through
race_planning: Brief crew on respiratory warning signs

historical_incidents.utmb_30km: Performance dip at 30km - classic vulnerable zone
historical_incidents.snowdonia: Lost inhaler mid-race but managed (ideal temps 13-16°C helped)
historical_incidents.arc_2025_15km: Incident at 15km in 4-8°C, no inhaler. Slowed down but continued to 4:23 finish. VALIDATES vulnerable zone (3-25km) and temperature trigger (<10°C)
historical_incidents.validation: Model accurately predicts incidents based on temp/effort. Arc proves can still race fast despite incident with proper management

technical_terrain_capability._discovery: KEY INSIGHT from multi-race validation - technical terrain is STRENGTH not weakness
technical_terrain_capability.competitive_advantage: +15 percentile points on technical races vs moderate terrain

runnable_trails.notes: Only 4% slower than road - this is athlete strength

runnable_coastal.notes: Fast coastal paths - validated 4:23 finish at 9.6 km/h average

technical_wet.notes: Wet rocks major slowdown but still competitive

steep_downhill_technical.notes: Rocky descents - most affected but still strong

flat_technical_gravel.notes: Actually FASTER on firm gravel paths!

skills_contributing: Good line choice and foot placement
Mental toughness to maintain pace on technical ground
technical_terrain_capability.race_selection_implication: FAVOR technical mountain races - field slows more than you do

temperature.notes: Cold is PRIMARY concern due to respiratory. Arc 2025 proved can race fast at 4-8°C with proper management (inhaler, conservative start). Heat less tested but likely moderate tolerance

altitude.notes: Respiratory sensitivity increases with altitude, especially when combined with cold

wind.notes: Wind compounds cold effect (windchill) and increases effort on exposed sections

precipitation.notes: Wet conditions primarily affect technical terrain speed

humidity.notes: High humidity in cold = more respiratory stress

nutrition_strategy._description: Validated nutrition parameters for ultra racing

night_racing.notes: Lower tolerance at night, easier on stomach

daylight_racing.notes: Can push intake higher in daylight hours

climbs_steep.notes: Hard to eat while climbing hard

descents.notes: Hard to eat while descending technical terrain

hydration.temperature_adjustment: Add 50ml/hr per degree above 15Â°C, reduce 50ml/hr per degree below 10Â°C

electrolytes.notes: Primarily sodium focus, standard electrolyte mix

caffeine.notes: Strategic use for alertness and performance boost

cold_weather_adjustments.prefer: Gels over chews (easier with cold hands)
cold_weather_adjustments.challenges: Harder to eat with cold/wet hands, practice in training
cold_weather_adjustments.storage: Keep key nutrition in jacket pockets (body warmth prevents freezing)

pacing_strategies._description: Validated pacing approaches with success rates

conservative.best_for: First attempt at competitive time, uncertain fitness, cold conditions

moderate.best_for: Balanced approach, known course, confident in fitness

aggressive.best_for: Strong fitness, great conditions, competitive goals

race_mode.best_for: Peak fitness (1.4+), perfect conditions, going for course record
race_mode.notes: Only works with fitness >1.4, respiratory management critical

respiratory_adjusted.rationale: Very conservative first 25km (vulnerable zone), increase once warm and past risk window

pre_race.gear_check: Inhaler accessible, nutrition in pockets, layers appropriate
pre_race.mental_prep: Accept conservative first 25km if cold, trust the plan

first_10km.focus: Warm up body and respiratory system

km_10_30_vulnerable_zone.action_if_issues: Immediate pace reduction, use inhaler, HR <130

km_30_plus.focus: Past vulnerable zone, can race harder

final_quarter.effort: All available if respiratory managed well
final_quarter.focus: Empty the tank, use mental toughness

race_suitability_matrix._description: Guide for race selection based on validated model

highly_suitable.examples: Arc of Attrition, Chianti 74K, Snowdonia (May), UK mountain ultras, coastal trail marathons

challenging.expected_performance: Survival mode, manage conditions > time goals

less_suitable.notes: Can complete but don't play to strengths

training_periodization._description: How fitness develops over training cycles

base_phase.focus: Build aerobic base, technical trail time

build_phase.focus: Increase volume, add intensity, long runs

taper_phase.notes: Proper taper critical for peak performance

realistic_timelines.notes: Cannot rush fitness - need consistent build

known_vulnerabilities: Ankle - twisted at Snowdonia but continued
strengths: Mental toughness to continue through discomfort

model_parameters_summary._description: Quick reference for digital twin model inputs

arc_of_attrition.strategy: Conservative first 15km, race hard post-vulnerable zone

timeline_challenge.issue: Only 4 weeks between marathon and Chianti
timeline_challenge.implication: Cannot build significant fitness in this window
timeline_challenge.strategy: Accept limited Chianti goals OR defer marathon to post-Chianti
timeline_challenge.arc_advantage: Arc in February allows proper taper before marathon

success_factors_ranked._description: What matters most for performance (in order)
success_factors_ranked.1_fitness_level: Primary determinant of pace - need 1.35+ for competitive ultras
success_factors_ranked.2_respiratory_management: Can derail race completely if cold - manage proactively
success_factors_ranked.3_temperature_conditions: Impacts both pace and respiratory - 15Â°C vs 8Â°C = 20% difference
success_factors_ranked.4_pacing_discipline: Right strategy for conditions = 10% better success rate
success_factors_ranked.5_technical_terrain: Athlete strength - faster relative to field on technical
success_factors_ranked.6_nutrition_execution: Solid plan = 10-15% performance vs poor nutrition
success_factors_ranked.7_mental_toughness: Proven in adversity (Snowdonia injury), key for tough conditions

key_insights.primary: Technical terrain AND runnable coastal paths are competitive advantages - seek mountain and coastal trail races
key_insights.secondary: Cold triggers respiratory incidents BUT can still race fast with proper management (Arc 4:23 at 4-8°C proves this)
key_insights.tertiary: Fitness 1.35+ needed for competitive ultra times - requires 24+ week build
key_insights.strategic: Race selection matters more than training volume - choose races that suit your profile
key_insights.arc_learning: 40-50km coastal/trail marathons are strength races - aim for competitive times, not just completion

validation_confidence.recommended_use: Race planning, training periodization, realistic goal setting
validation_confidence.key_learning: Arc 2025 proved course-specific data beats descriptions. Respiratory model triggers validated perfectly

historical_training_context._description: Long-horizon training history derived from Veloviewer/Strava exports. This is separate from Garmin/TrainingPeaks CTL and should not be mixed without calibration.

ctl_proxy_definition.input: Weekly sum of Activity Score for running activities

weather_exposure_profile._description: Weather parsed from Veloviewer Description field. Use as exposure priors, not as exact course weather.

definitions.cold_exposure: Weekly moving time (hours) for runs where parsed temperature < threshold

next_calibrations: Calibrate Activity Score -> CTL mapping against the CTL numbers used in race_history (likely TrainingPeaks/Garmin load). Keep both as separate series until mapped.
Use weather_exposure_profile to adjust respiratory multipliers based on recent cold exposure (habituation) vs detraining.
Use weekly elevation density (elv_m/dist_km) to refine technical_terrain multipliers by season and training block.
Add shoe-level fatigue/injury signals using Gear field once shoe names are standardized.

chianti_74k.notes: Removes alpine altitude drag and reduces UTMB-style fatigue for runnable sub-80k profile. Adds field-loss factor where you gain relative time.

similar_runner_calibration._description: Calibration based on similar runner performance at Chianti 74K

estimated_fitness_for_target.notes: Based on Arc pace extrapolation and runnable terrain advantage

pace_comparison.rationale: Chianti is more runnable than Snowdonia but longer than Arc. Expected pace between the two.

key_success_factors: Fitness 1.15-1.20 (aggressive but achievable with focused training)

runnable_trails._description: Athlete's advantage on runnable trail terrain
runnable_trails.notes: Field loses ~5% more time than athlete on runnable sections. This is the athlete's strength.
evidence: Arc 2025: Top 30% on highly runnable course

short_climbs._description: Athlete's advantage on repeated short climbs (6-16%)
short_climbs.notes: Better at maintaining rhythm on rolling terrain than extended alpine climbing
